bibl.title: Senate Report No. 6009, 59th Congress, 2d Session, February 2, 1907

div1.p: This report concerns James Carroll.

div1.head: Senate Report No. 6009, 59th Congress, 2d Session, February 2, 1907
div1.p:
59TH CONGRESS,}
2d Session.}
SENATE.

{REPORT
{No. 6009.
JAMES CARROLL.

Mr. WARREN, from the Committee on Military Affairs, submitted the
following
REPORT.
[To accompany S. 5888.]

The Committee on Military Affairs, having had under careful consid-
eration the bill (S. 5888) authorizing the President to place James Car-
roll on the retired list with the rank of major, reports the bill
favorably and recommends the following amendment:

Strike out all after the article “a” in line 6, and insert in lieu thereof
the following: “surgeon with the rank of major in the Medical Corps
of the Army, and that the number of officers in the Medical Corps be
increased by one, with the rank of major, for this purpose.”

Amend the title so as to read: “A bill authorizing the President to
appoint James Carroll a surgeon with the rank of major in the United
States Army.”

And your committee further recommends that, when so amended, the
bill be passed.

This action is taken in appreciation and because of the exceptionally
heroic service performed by James Carroll in the interest of his country
and of science in submitting himself for experiment during the investi-
gation in Cuba as to the causes and best mode of eradication of yellow
fever.
THE WAR DEPARTMENT'S OPINION OF JAMES CARROLL'S SERVICE.
[First indorsement.]

WAR DEPARTMENT,
THE MILITARY SECRETARY'S OFFICE,
Washington, April 28, 1906.

Respectfully referred to the Surgeon-General of the Army for remark.
By order of the Acting Secretary of War:

F. C. AINSWORTH,
The Military Secretary.
JAMES CARROLL.
[Second indorsement.]

WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON-GENERAL,
April 30, 1906.
Respectfully returned to The Military Secretary.

Lieut. James Carroll, assistant surgeon, entered the service January 9, 1874, and
had nine years' service as private, sergeant, and first sergeant of infantry, followed by
sixteen years as hospital steward. Having shown ability for laboratory work and
having graduated in medicine, he was appointed contract surgeon May 23, 1898, and
afterwards first lieutenant and assistant surgeon October 27, 1902.

Doctor Carroll went to Cuba as a member of the commission to investigate yellow
fever in June, 1900, and distinguished himself as a member of that board, not only
by his scientific work as a member of the commission, but also for having offered
himself for experiment to demonstrate the transmission of yellow fever by the
mosquito. He suffered in this way a very severe attack of the disease, being the
first case of experimental yellow fever. He was commended by the Hon. Elihu
Root, Secretary of War, in his report for the year 1902, for his share in connection
with the great scientific achievement of that commission.

He is at present curator of the Army Medical Museum and in charge of the labora-
tory of the Surgeon-General's office.

He is, in my opinion, far too valuable a man to be placed on the retired list as
provided by this bill. I recommend, therefore, that this bill be passed, so amended
as to give Doctor Carroll the grade of major on the active list, the number of majors
in the Medical Corps being increased by one for this purpose.

Doctor Carroll will be 52, years old in June, and stands 162 on the list of assistant
surgeons. There is thus but little prospect under present conditions of his reaching
the grade of major before his retirement in any other way than by a special act of
Congress.

R. M. O'RIELLY,
Surgeon-General U. S. Army.
{Third indorsement.]

WAR DEPARTMENT,
THE MILITARY SECRETARY'S OFFICE,
Washington, May 1, 1906.

Respectfully returned to the Secretary of War, inviting attention to the remarks
and recommendation of the Surgeon-General in his foregoing indorsement hereon.

F. C. AINSWORTH,
The Military Secretary.
[Fourth indorsement.]
WAR DEPARTMENT, May 9, 1906.

Respectfully returned to the chairman Committee on Military Affairs, United
States Senate, inviting attention to the foregoing report of the Surgeon-General of
the Army, in whose views the Department concurs.

This case is one of exceptional merit, and it is thought fully justifies the unusual
action here proposed.

WM. H. TAFT,
Secretary of War.

PROCEEDINGS IN THE NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL
ASSOCIATION, WASHINGTON, D. C., DECEMBER, 1906.

December 13.--The case of Dr. James Carroll and the bill for his relief introduced
by Hon. Charles Dick, of Ohio, and now pending in the United States Senate, having
been formally brought to the attention of the council by the chairman, Dr. A. S.
von Mansfelde, representative from the Medical Association of the State of Nebraska,
moved to refer the subject to a special committee, with instruction to report at the
present meeting of the council.

The motion, having been duly seconded, was formally put and unanimously carried
by a standing vote.

The chairman thereupon appointed A. S. von Mansfelde (Nebraska), C. Z. Aude
(Kentucky), and S. D. Van Meter (Colorado) as such committee.
JAMES CARROLL.

December 14.--On call, the special committee, to which was referred the chairman's
remarks relative to Dr. James Carroll, reported as follows:

"Whereas the chairman of this council, Dr. Charles A. L. Reed, in his address to
this body uses this language:

“The ultimate completion of the Panama Canal, the present salubrity of Cuba, the
safety of our southern seaboard against periodic invasion by epidemics, the main-
tenance of life and health of our citizens in that great section, and the stability of
our national commerce against disturbance from the same cause are all made possible
by the discovery that the mosquito is the carrier of the contagion of yellow fever.
That fact was established by the labors of three men, two of whom, in the interests of
humanity and science, subjected themselves to inoculation by infected mosquitoes.
As a result of that experiment, one of them, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, within the next
few days, died a martyr's death; the other, Dr. James Carroll, survived to live a
martyr's life. The only reward that he has so far received is a disease of the heart
that occurred as the result of the yellow fever that he voluntarily contracted for the
welfare of his race. This man, this hero, after risking his life to give this priceless
boon to the world, after incurring a permanent invalidism in that cause, after having
spent thirty-four years in the faithful service of his country, is permitted to remain
only an assistant surgeon with the rank of first lieutenant in the United States Army,
with the paltry salary of an officer of this grade, and with broken health this man,
far past the meridian of life, is supposed to meet the obligations resting upon a hus-
band, the father of seven children, and to provide against the requirements of old
age.”
(This is about both of them)

The special committee appointed to pass upon said remarks of the chairman do
most emphatically approve the same and recommend that this council, as the repre-
sentative body of the medical profession of America, urge upon the President and
Congress to make such investigation and take such action as will mete out a full
measure of justice to Dr. James Carroll and to the family of the late Dr. Jesse W.
Lazear.

It is further recommended that the medical members of Congress be respectfully
requested to use their utmost power to accomplish this end.

A. S. v. MANSFELDE, Chairman.
C. Z. AUDE,
S. D. VAN METER.
MILITARY RECORD OF JAMES CARROLL.

Born in England June 5, 1854. Enlisted in Company E, First Infantry, January
9, 1874. Promoted corporal May 1, 1874. Sergeant January 1, 1875, until discharged
sergeant January 9, 1879.

Reenlisted as private in Company C, Seventh Infantry, January 22, 1879. Pro-
moted sergeant from private February 1, 1879.
Appointed first sergeant June 20, 1879.
Served in campaign against Ute Indians October, 1879, to June, 1880.
Resigned as sergeant to take furlough November 14, 1882.
Reappointed first sergeant and detailed as second-class hospital steward April 7, 1883.
Appointed hospital steward from sergeant September 15, 1883.
Detailed for duty at Columbia Exposition, Chicago, about May 1, 1893.
Detailed for duty at the Army Medical Museum about November 1, 1893.

Service continuous as hospital steward until discharged on May 21, 1898. Appointed
contract (A. A. Asst.) surgeon May 22, 1898, and assigned to duty in the laboratory of
the Surgeon-General's Office by an order dated Surgeon-General's Office, May 22, 1898.

Detailed as a member of the army board for the study of infectious diseases in the
island of Cuba, in association with Maj. Walter Reed and Acting Assistant Surgeons
Anstides, Agramonte, and Jesse W. Lazear, per paragraphs 33 and 34, Special Orders,
No. 122, Adjutant-General's Office, May 24, 1900. In the course of their experiments
he voluntarily submitted to the bite of an infected mosquito August 27, 1900, and
was taken sick with yellow fever August 31, 1900, suffering a severe attack. His was
the first case of experimental yellow fever. He was confined strictly to bed until
September 13, and, convalescence being slow, he left Cuba October 9, 1900, on sick
leave, returning for duty November 11, 1900. He took part in all the experimental
work of the board, made nearly all of the experimental inoculations, and had charge
of the infected mosquitoes until March 4, 1904, one month after the departure of
4
JAMES CARROLL.
Major Reed. At this time he had been recommended for appointment to a volunteer
majority by Gen. Leonard Wood and Surgeon-General Sternberg, but Secretary
Root decided that no more appointments would be made. After returning from
Cuba his time was devoted to the study of mosquitoes that had been infected and
preserved for the purpose. In August he again proceeded to Cuba, under orders,
alone, for the purpose of performing additional experimental work, in which he pro-
duced six more experimental cases of yellow fever, all of which ended in recovery.
In 1903 he showed by experimental demonstration that the supposed protozoon
parasites reported to have been found in yellow fever infected mosquitoes were ordi
nary yeast cells.

He was assigned by General Sternberg in 1897 to the work of studying the sup-
posed cause of yellow fever, in association with Maj. Walter Reed, and in this work
it was shown that the supposed cause of yellow fever described by Professor Sanarelli
was closely related to the hog cholera bacillus.

In 1898 he was sent to Camp Alger to study the blood of the fever patients, and
he was the first to show and reported to General Sternberg that the prevailing illness
among the troops was typhoid and not malarial fever. He was then ordered to
Camp Cuba Libra, Jacksonville, Fla., for similar work, and his results were included
in the report of the typhoid fever board. He was subsequently ordered to Camp
Chickamauga to obtain samples of the waters in use and to examine them
bacteriologically.

His service as contract surgeon continued until October 26, 1902, and on October
27, 1902, he was appointed first lieutenant and assistant surgeon in the Medical Corps,
the age limit having been waived to permit him to appear for examination. He was
assigned to duty as assistant curator of the Army Medical Museum by paragraph 20,
Special Orders, No. 257, dated Adjutant-General's Office, November 1, 1902, and as
professor of bacteriology and clinical microscopy at the Army Medical School by an
order dated Surgeon-General's Office, November 20, 1902, having previously served as
assistant during every session of the school. Was appointed curator of the Army
Medical Museum by an order of the Surgeon-General, dated July 3, 1903. He has
performed the above duties continuously since appointment to them and will have
completed thirty-three years' continuous service in the Army on January 21, 1907.

He studied medicine at the University of the City of New York during the session
of 1886-87 and at the University of Maryland in the sessions of 1889-90 and 1890-91,
graduating in the latter year. He took a post-graduate course in pathology under
Professor Welch at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1891-92 and in bacteriology in the
winter of 1892-93.

He assisted Major Reed in the department of bacteriology and pathology of the
Columbian (now George Washington) University from the session of 1895-96 until
the death of Major Reed, whom he has now succeeded as professor of those subjects,
which he teaches to evening classes.

He was suggested for a share of the Nobel prize by an editorial in the British
Medical Journal for September 8, 1906.

Membership in societies.--Society of American Bacteriologists, ex-vice-president;
American Society of Pathologists and Bacteriologists; Washington Academy of Sci-
ences; American Public Health Association; honorary member of the Medical
Society of Manila; Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Sci-
ence; member of the Society of American Naturalists; member of the Washington
Biological Society.

head.hi: List of publications by Dr. Carroll.

list.item: 1. The Treatment of Yellow Fever. Journal A. M. A., 1902, xxxiv, 117-124.

2. The Etiology of Yellow Fever--an addendum. Journal A. M. A., 1903, xli,
1341-1344.
3. The Transmission of Yellow Fever. Journal A. M. A., 1903, xli, 43.
4. The Alleged Parasite of Yellow Fever. Med. Record, N. Y., 1903, lxiii, 25.

5. Remarks on the History, Cause, and Mode of Transmission of Yellow Fever
and the Occurrence of Similar Types of Fatal Fevers in Places where Yellow Fever
is not Known to Have Existed. Journ. Assn. of Mil. Surg. U. S., Carlisle, Pa., 1903,
xiii, 177-210.

6. A Brief Review of the Etiology of Yellow Fever. N. Y. Med. Jour., 1904,
lxxix, 241-245.

7. The Discovery of the Transmission of Yellow Fever by the Mosquito. Ameri-
can Med., Phila., 1904, viii, 583.

8. Yellow Fever: A Popular Lecture. Forms No. 62, of Bull. Univ. of Texas,
Med. Series No. 1. Also Amer. Med., Phila., 1905, ix, 907-915.
JAMES CARROLL.

9. Lessons to be Learned from the Present Outbreak of Yellow Fever in Louisiana.
Journal A. M. A., 1905, xlv, 1079-1081.

10. Remarks on the Epidemics of Yellow Fever in Baltimore. Old Maryland,
Balt., 1906, ii, 17-23.

11. Without Mosquitoes There Can Be no Yellow Fever. Science, N. Y., and Lan-
caster, Pa., 1905, N. S. xxiii, 401-407. Also Amer. Med., Phila., 1906, xii, 383-386.

12. The Microscope in Its Relation to Medicine. The Bulletin of the University
of Nebraska, College of Medicine, vol. xxi, No. 3, 1906.

13. Yellow Fever in New Orleans and its Bearing on the Health of the State.
New Orleans Med. and Surg. Jour., September, 1906, 180-195.

14. Text-book Article on Yellow Fever. Dr. C. Mense's Handb. de Tropenkrank.,
Leipzig, 1905, ii, pp. 108-139.
15. Notis. Gelt fieber betreffend. Centrlbl. f. Bact., Jena, 1904, xxxvii, 666-668.

16. Yellow Fever, Osler's Text-book on Medicine. Now in the hands of the
publishers.

17. Pathological Report and Histological Study of an Endothelioma of the Cere-
bellum, with some General Remarks on the Difference between the Cells of Endo-
thelium and of Epithelium. George Washington University Bulletin.

head.hi: List of publications by Carroll and others.

list.item:
18. Bacillus Icteroides and Bacillus Choleræ Suis. A Preliminary Note. By Reed
and Carroll. Med. News, N. Y., 1899, 513.

19. The Specific Cause of Yellow Fever. A Reply to Dr. G. Sanarelli. By Reed
and Carroll. Med. News, N. Y., Sept. 9, 1899.

20. The Etiology of Yellow Fever. A Preliminary Note. By Reed, Carroll,
Agramonte and Lazear. Phila. Med. Jour., 1900, vi, 790-796.

21. A Comparative Study of the Biological Characters and Pathogenesis of Bacillus
X (Sternberg), Bacillus Icteroides (Sanarelli) and the Hog Cholera Bacillus (Salmon
and Smith). By Reed and Carroll. Jour. Exper. Med., vol. v, No. 3, 215-270.

22. The Etiology of Yellow Fever: An Additional Note. By Reed, Carroll, and
Agramonte. Journal A. M. A., 1901, xxxvi, 431-440.

23. Experimental Yellow Fever. By Reed, Carroll, and Agramonte. Tran. Amer.
Phys., vol. xvi, 1901. Also Amer. Med., Phila., July, 1901.

24. The Prevention of Yellow Fever. By Reed and Carroll. Med. Record, Oct.
26, 1901.

25. The Etiology of Yellow Fever (a Supplemental Note). By Reed and Carroll.
Amer. Med., Feb. 22, 1902.

26. Leprosy. Report of Surgeon-General U. S. Army, Washington, 1902-3, pp.
65-69. By Carroll and Gilchrist.

27. Microscopical Report of a Case of Fungus Foot. Amer. Jour. Med. Sci.,
Philadelphia, 1899, N. S. cxviii, 394-399.

div1.p:
Dr Carroll elected honorary member of the
Nebraska Academy of Science. (I am an ex president)
in January 1907, last month.

Dr. Carroll elected by the Board of Regints to
receive the degree of L. L. D. from the University
at the of Nebraska at the June 1907 commencement.
